messageBody:
Hi David,

Could you possibly elaborate on "I can't comment on the history of
assertNotEquals" - I've also been a little puzzled at this perceived gap
in the JUnit 3.8.x API and would be interested to learn a bit more about
the reason(s) behind it.

I agree that Assert#assertThrows is a little on the tricky side.
Personally, I've always gone for:

<snip>
try
{
Integer.parseInt("not an int");
fail("Should not be able to parse String as int.");
}
catch (Throwable expectedT)
{
assertInstanceOf(expectedT, IllegalArgumentException.class);
}
</snip>

I'm willing to hear about other solutions, mind - provided that it
doesn't involve upgrading to JUnit 4. Not an option right now. :(

Regards,

Steve.

--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

David Saff wrote:
> Nitay wrote:
>> I've been using junit for a while now. These days every piece of java
>> snippet I write has a test attached to it :).
>
> That's cool. I hope it's helping the design and implementation of your
> code--I know it helps mine.
>
>> I was wondering why there are no assertNotEquals and assertThrows
>> methods in
>> the Assert class. I have needed something like this many times in my
>> testing, and have had to fall back to doing assertFalse(a.equals(b)) and a
>> sequence of try-catch-fail, respectively.
>
> I can't comment on the history of assertNotEquals. assertThrows is hard
> in a language like Java that doesn't have literal code blocks, but JUnit
> 4 handles it with the @Test(expected=NullPointerException.class) annotation.
>
